posts.name: Jonah Bonner
posts.cooked:
The text presents a comprehensive overview of AdvantageKit, focusing on its template projects, features, updates, and documentation. Here's a concise summary:

AdvantageKit is a powerful logging and replay framework designed for robotics and automation. It offers extensive template projects tailored to various Spark and Vision swerve platforms, simplifying setup and providing ready-to-use configurations. Key features include advanced logging capabilities, such as multi-value logging, pose observation logging, and alerts management. The platform supports both traditional and modern logging methods, ensuring efficient data handling and retrieval. Recent updates include a revised build system, improved documentation, and enhanced stability. The text emphasizes hands-on learning through template projects, while also highlighting ongoing developments and transitions within the AdvantageKit ecosystem. For further exploration, visit the official documentation or explore the GitHub repository. Additional resources, including social media handles and Maven repositories, are available for those interested in contributing or staying updated.

posts.cooked: I am very much looking forward to this year's release posts. Goodbye to shimming! I am genuinely excited to see how things play out this year.

An image is linked here for viewing. However, there appears to be confusion regarding documentation accessibility. While the official documentation can be found at docs.advantagekit.org, it is noted as potentially dangerous. Additionally, it is mentioned that while it can be accessed from a personal hotspot, it would be more convenient to have it available normally. For reference, the markdown source for these documentation files is available at github.com/Mechanical-Advantage/AdvantageKit/tree/main/docs/docs.

posts.name: Jonah Bonner
posts.cooked: We‚Äôve seen a couple of reports of advantagekit.org being blocked by firewalls because the domain was registered within the last few months. The markdown source can be accessed at the link you found, and it should also be possible to browse the site using a cellular hotspot. We expect the issue to clear up over time once the domain is no longer marked as recently registered.

Also having the same issue with the domain being blocked on the network I'm usually on (not my network). I also fixed it by switching to my personal cell hotspot although I just got a cannot connect error.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Can you hand me the funny thing (the ziptie gun)?

posts.name: Brett B Bonner
posts.cooked:
To be clear, this is a client-side blocking issue, not a problem with the documentation site (which has a current, valid certificate and is hosted through GitHub Pages).  

The advantagescope.org and advantagekit.org domains were registered in mid September, 2024, and as mentioned by @jonahb55 some of the security appliance vendors by default block ‚Äúnewly registered domains‚Äù as they are frequently used by malicious actors. Since we are now several months past registration, hopefully we‚Äôre past that window, but some filters may also block any sites with programming information as ‚Äúhacking‚Äù by default.  

We recommend contacting your IT or support department to have these domains unblocked or whitelisted.

posts.name: Greg Billetdeaux
posts.cooked:
These templates are very dope. I‚Äôve been building out simulation stuff over the past few months, and these templates have surpassed everything I did, offering a seamless experience. I‚Äôm genuinely impressed.  

When implementing TalonFX, what key differences exist between this approach and the subsystem code generated by CTRE‚Äôs Swerve Generator? While both adhere to the IO paradigm, which ensures consistent architectural design across the application, TalonFX offers a level of simplicity I hadn‚Äôt experienced before. It streamlines the drivetrain configuration, allowing me to ‚Äúset it and forget it,‚Äù which aligns perfectly with my preference for ease of use and reduced complexity.

posts.name: Jonah Bonner
posts.cooked:
The critical difference between the AdvantageKit template and CTRE‚Äôs swerve library is that our template allows the entire swerve stack to be accessed in replay. This includes the pose estimator, which is particularly useful for tuning in replay (especially with replay watch). The CTRE library needs to be isolated to an IO implementation, where elements like the pose estimator and kinematics can‚Äôt be debugged in replay (and of course, using it outside an IO implementation isn‚Äôt an option because that would break deterministic replay for the whole project).

The AdvantageKit code is designed to closely match the capabilities of the CTRE swerve code, with support for features like automatic calibration (with Tuner X), high-frequency odometry, on-controller PID, fused/sync/remote CANcoders, and CANivore time sync (for CANivore/Pheonix Pro users). It also includes a few features that aren‚Äôt part of the CTRE code, like on-robot feedforward and wheel radius characterization routines and integration with persistent alerts for disconnected devices. It can also be used with a combination of hardware from different vendors, such replacing the Pigeon 2 with a NavX (more complex changes require writing additional code, in line with the philosophy discussed below).

The biggest difference is that the projects have significantly different APIs, where the AdvantageKit template is focused around a relatively basic drive subsystem and includes several example commands (for field-relative drive and auto aiming). Our philosophy is to support all of the basics that teams have come to expect, but make the project as easy as possible to expand and customize (with no black boxes). This differs a bit from the apparent objectives of CTRE‚Äôs library, but we feel it aligns better with the goals of AdvantageKit and log replay (intended for experienced users who are interested in having more control).

One implementation difference between the CTRE and AdvantageKit code is that CTRE runs the kinematics and odometry thread in native code. Theoretically this is more performant, but we haven‚Äôt seen any evidence that it makes a difference for practical applications. The AdvantageKit templates perform very well even in pure Java, so I don‚Äôt think this should be a major consideration.

We have made every effort to maximize the stability and performance of the AdvantageKit swerve templates. They have been tested on the RIO 1 and RIO 2, and we‚Äôve worked with several teams to alpha-test the projects before release. However, these are still beta releases and subject to change. As with any beta version, I would recommend waiting for the kickoff release if you‚Äôre particularly concerned about having a smooth experience.

posts.name: Yishai Levy
posts.cooked: I'm curious, why the switch to logged mechanism 2d? May have missed it, but I haven't seen the reason in the docs.

posts.name: Jonah Bonner
posts.cooked:
This is related to the removal of shims. We need to be able to read the internal state of a Mechanism2d for logging, without relying on NetworkTables or the Sendable interface. This was previously achieved by adding additional methods to Mechanism2d and its related classes (which weren‚Äôt part of the standard interface). The simplest alternative is to provide our own versions of the classes for now, though we may revisit this in the future (especially with potential changes to Sendable under discussion).

The ‚Äúlogged‚Äù versions of these classes are identical to the WPILib implementations, so switching just requires swapping the class name and import path.

posts.name: Yishai Levy
posts.cooked: The "logged" versions of these classes are identical to the WPILib implementations, so switching just requires swapping the class name and import path.

posts.name: Jonah Bonner
posts.cooked: The other logged classes are specifically used for input logging, so they essentially act as pre-built IO interfaces. Mechanism objects have always been used as outputs, so the implementation can almost entirely match the standard classes.

posts.name: Greg Billetdeaux
posts.cooked: Thanks for the thorough response! I definitely see the appeal. I think you‚Äôve convinced me to give it a shot. Porting my simulation project to this and check it out.

The biggest difference is that the projects have significantly different APIs, where the AdvantageKit template focuses on a relatively basic drive subsystem and includes several example commands (for field-relative drives and auto aiming). Our philosophy is to support all the basics expected by teams but make the project as simple as possible to expand and customize (without black boxes). This differs a bit from the apparent objectives of the CTRE project‚Äôs library. What are some features of the CTRE project that the new AK template doesn‚Äôt include? I fully grasp the reasoning behind this approach, but I‚Äôm curious about what, if anything, we might be missing by not utilizing the CTRE project.

posts.name: Jonah Bonner
posts.cooked:
The critical difference between these libraries lies in their approach to log replay. Users not interested in log replay should consider using Epilogue instead of CTRE‚Äôs Swerve framework. On the other hand, users interested in log replay will benefit significantly from using the AdvantageKit template alongside the CTRE Swerve requests. While both libraries offer substantial similarities, they differ in their design philosophies‚Äîone expects users to customize from the start, whereas the other aims to abstract complexity for most users.

CTRE‚Äôs Swerve library is built around swerve requests, which include built-in controllers and kinematics. These requests operate at a higher frequency than the regular loop cycle. The AdvantageKit template, however, uses a different structure, featuring a generic setter for velocity setpoints. It also includes predefined commands for common tasks like field-oriented joystick drive, auto aiming, feedforward characterization, and wheel radius measurement. Users may need to customize these commands, unlike CTRE‚Äôs more streamlined API.

Our approach emphasizes customization for users already interested in log replay, while CTRE‚Äôs aim is to simplify complexity for most users. Both libraries cater to different audiences, but we believe our template is better suited for users exploring log replay capabilities.

A few features are intentionally omitted from our libraries, such as coupling ratio, a 254-style swerve setpoint generator, and advanced physics simulation. These can be integrated by users who need them. While CTRE‚Äôs library includes coupling ratio, it does not feature the swerve setpoint generator or advanced simulation. Documentation explains these options and how to integrate with non-CTRE hardware.

Our template may lag behind in supporting new hardware, such as the Talon FXS. Updates depend on CTRE releasing their TunerConstants file, limiting our ability to test hardware variations. Thus, our focus is on providing a flexible starting point for users who want to experiment with bleeding-edge hardware.

posts.cooked: Thank you for the detailed breakdown. I truly appreciate the open-source nature of AdvantageKit compared to the CTRE project, ensuring we aren't overlooking any crucial 'secret sauce' that could enhance auto reliability or teleop responsiveness. Thank you for your hard work on this update!

posts.name: Daniel C.
Jonah Bonner
posts.cooked: I think you already got an answer, but NT has a standard json type that will be decoded by AdvantageScope. I'm not familiar enough with DogLog to comment on how to use it to publish specific NT types.

posts.name: meer
posts.cooked: Just wondering what exactly is the benefit of logging the Radio data? Do you think it can be used when making calls to the refs for disconnects or other things or is it just a useful source of data for system checks?

posts.name: Jonah Bonner
posts.cooked: AdvantageKit radio logging is not an official source for referee calls on the field. It is mainly used for diagnosing issues while teams practice and occasionally helps debug other radio problems encountered on the field.
